text:
Hi goog day

Do you know how to calculate big int accuracy ?
julia> big(200000000009)/big(10^9)
200.0000000089999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999996

actually I wish that the result is 200.000000009

elements.text:

text: The problem here is that this is correct up to `.5` ULP. Dividing `BigInt`s gives a `BigFloat`

elements.text: The problem here is that this is correct up to

text: I think the limit here is `precision(BigFloat)`, which returns 256 on my system and  `BigFloat("200.000000009")`  displays as 200.0000000089999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999996

elements.text: I think the limit here is
, which returns 256 on my system and

text:
(a) you can set the precision for BigFloats: `setprecision(BigFloat, 512)`
(b) it is safest to initialize a BigFloat with the number you intend as a string if you are working with base 10, or else to consider that Julia determines the Float64 result of e.g. `sqrt(2)` before BigFloat gets the value in `BigFloat(sqrt(2))` so `sqrt(BigFloat(2))` would be the way to write that.

elements.text: (a) you can set the precision for BigFloats:

before BigFloat gets the value in

text:
Also there is the package `DecFP`  (for larger numbers use `Dec128` from the same package)
```julia> using DecFP
julia> Dec64(200000000009) / Dec64(10)^11
2.00000000009```
it’s an display issue, one could display the same BigFloat number as <tel:200.0000|200.0000>0009
